eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Silver-Streak, @Bouh, Tristan Rhodes
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: IsOnScreen
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This adds a condition to detect if an object is on screen based off its current layer.
description: This extension adds conditions to check if an object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that this does not take into account any object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, but can be combined with those existing conditions.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
This behavior provides a condition to check if the object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, is not considered (but you can use those existing conditions in addition to this behavior).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: InOnScreen

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if an object position is within the viewport of its layer.
eventsFunctions.name: IsOnScreen

inlineCode: Get the object layer, convert the position from this layer to the screen coordinates.
Get the point on each side on the object on screen, and compare with the screen area.
This way even if the camera has a rotation or custom scale the object is always compared to the screen area.
// Get the layer of the object.
// Get the aabb of the object on his layer.
// Get the layer to convert the coordinates of the AABB to the screen coordinates
// Get the points on each side of the object on screen.
const posLeftObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posRightObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posUpObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);
const posDownObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);

parameters.longDescription: Number of pixels to pad the screen border. Zero by default. A negative value goes inside the screen, a positive value go outside.
parameters.name: Padding

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (tristan@victrisgames.com), Entropy
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ScreenWrap
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Teleport object when it moves off the screen and immediately appear on the opposite side while maintaining speed and trajectory.
description: The teleport happens when the center point of the object crosses a border (this can be adjusted with an offset).
By default, the borders of the wrapping area match the screen size, but they can alo be changed.
The Asteroid-like example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-asteroid)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Teleport the object when leaving one side of the screen so that it immediately reappears on the opposite side, maintaining speed and trajectory.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ScreenWrap

events.name: Move object to opposite side (if needed)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: 4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Parallax
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
description: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
- The parallax now starts with an offset of 0.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera horizontally with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Horizontal Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: HorizontalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment:
- The left side of the camera is used to have the left side of the image at X = 0 in the scene.
  This also allows the image to keep the same location when the window ratio changes.

- The camera left side is calculated for a zoom of 1 instead of using CameraBorderLeft() that use the current zoom.
  It allows the image to keep the same location when the zoom change.

(CameraCenterX(FollowedLayer) - CameraWidth(FollowedLayer) / 2 * CameraZoom(FollowedLayer)) * ParallaxFactor

When a zoom changes, the object size in the scene also change to cover the screen.
This part of the formula takes this into account:

(CameraZoom(Object.Layer()) - 1) * CameraWidth(Object.Layer()) / 2

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera vertically with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Vertical Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: VerticalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment: See the comment in the other behavior for an explanation of this formula.

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer
